titlestmt.title: PCT 40: Crooken-Moccasin and the Bony Spectre
titlestmt.author: Adam Sakewew

bibl.title: Plains Cree Texts
bibl.series: Publications of the American Ethnological Society, Volume XVI

encodingdesc.p: This electronic document is oriented more toward representing those features that seem most likely to be relevant for grammatical analyses, rather than toward faithfully representing all the information available in the book.

list.item: 2014 06 10; KR; UTF-8, paragraph and sentence numbering, smart-quotes in English translations

body.head: PCT 40: Crooked-Moccasin and the bony spectre

p.seg: pêyak nâpêw kotokwaskisin isiyîhkâsôw . A certain man was called Crooked-Moccasin.
êkwah kîtahtawê kîksêpâ sipwêhtêw , êh-mâcît , ê-wîh-kakwê-nipahât pisiskiwah . Once upon a time he set out in the morning, to hunt, meaning to kill some game.
wâpahtam mitoni kîksêpâ êh-mihcêniyikih mîkiwâhpah . Early in the morning he saw a great many tipis.
êkwah êh-pimohtêt mêkwâc , kîtahtawê paskwâw wâpahtam ; wâsakâm sakâyiw . As he walked along, presently he saw an open meadow; round about were woods.
êwako nika-taskamohtân , êy-itêyihtahk , kîtahtawê ka-wâpamât ayîsiyiniwah êh-pê-matâwisiyit . “I shall walk across this,” he was thinking, when he saw a man come into the open.
nîmipâskisikanêyiwa . That person was carrying a gun.

tâwâyihk paskwâhk êh-pimohtêt awa kotokwaskisin ,
nâha kotak ayîsiyiniw , itêyihtam ,
kêhcinâ nikâ-têpâskîskawâw , itêyihtam . As Crooked-Moccasin was walking in the middle of the meadow, “Yonder man,” he thought, “surely I shall meet him as our paths cross,” he thought.
pôtih tâpwê têpâskîskawêw . It really turned out that he encountered the other at the point where their ways crossed.

sêmâk wîhik :
yahô , kotokwaskisin ! kêswân êtokê nêkiskotâtoyahk ! At once the other called him by name: “Yoho, Crooked-Moccasin! It is by chance, I suppose, that we meet!”
êhag , itêw . “Yes,” he answered him.
êkosi ômis îtik , pêskis êh-pâhpit awa kâ-nakiskâkêt ; Then the other spoke thus to him, and at the same time he laughed, who had encountered him;
ê-kitâpamât , awîn âwa , pâkahkos awa kâ-pâhpit ; when he looked at him, why, that person who laughed was a Bony Spectre.

ômis îtêw :
kotokwaskisin , kakwê-sâkohitotân ! This he said to him: “Crooked-Moccasin, let us try to overcome each other!

seg.q: kipâskisikaninawa astwâtotân ; awiyak sâkohihcih kit-ôtahwâw opâskisikan .
seg.gloss: Let us put up our guns as a stake; whoever is overcome will lose his gun.”

p.seg:
namoya , itêw kotokwaskisin ;
namoya ê-papâ-mâsihkêyân , itêw . “No,” Crooked-Moccasin told him; “I am not going about wrestling,” he told him.

seg.gloss: “No, Crooked-Moccasin; please, let us wrestle.

p.seg: awiyak sâkohihcih kit-ôtahwâw opâskisikan , itwêw awa pâkahkos . Whichever is defeated will lose his gun,” said the Bony Spectre.
namoya ! namoya êh-papa-mêtawêyân ; pisiskiw ê-wîh-kakwê-nipahak , itêw ôhi pâkahkosah . “No! I am not going about to engage in matches; I want to kill game,” he told the Bony Spectre.

seg.gloss: “Oh, please, let us wrestle.
It will be fine, when one of us loses his gun.
If you defeat me, you will have two guns.

seg.q: pêyak nama wîhkâc ka-patahikâhkân , nipâskisikan otahoyani .
seg.gloss: With one you will never miss the mark, if you win my gun from me.

seg.q: êkwah niya otahotânih , nôhtâwiy nka-miyâw ayîsiyiniw opâskisikan .
seg.gloss: And if I win yours, I shall give my father a human being's gun.
Because he wants to see one, is why I have come here to meet you.

seg.q: nka-kakwê-otahwâw opâskisikan , êh-itêyimitân , êwako ohci k-ôh-pê-nakiskâtân .
seg.gloss: 'I shall try to win his gun from him,' was my thought concerning you, owing to which I have come here and met you.”
“Well, you urge me too much!”

p.seg: astâw opâskisikan awa kotokwaskisin ; awa minah pâkahkos . Crooked-Moccasin put down his gun; so did the Bony Spectre.
otihtinitôwak , ê-wîh-kakwê-kawiwêpinitocik . They grappled, trying to throw each other.
mâsihitowak . They wrestled.

mwêhcih êh-nayawît awa kotokwaskisin , âcikêhwêw ; pakamisiniyiwa , êh-kawiwêpinât ôhi pâkahkosah . Just as Crooked-Moccasin was tiring, he tripped the other; he threw the Bony Spectre, who fell hard on the ground.
pâhpiw awa pâkahkos . The Bony Spectre laughed.
nitakah kiskât nipiswahên , itik ôhi pâkahkosa ; “By chance I stumbled over your leg,” the Bony Spectre said to him;
êkwah êyâpic pêyakwâw ! itik . “Come, once more!” he said to him.

seg.gloss: “Very well!”

p.seg: otihtinitôwak ; âsay mîna mâsihitôwak . They grappled; they wrestled again.
kêyâpic ê-wih-nawayît , âcikêhwêw pâkahkosah ; âsay mîna kawiwêpinêw . Once more, as he was about to give out, he tripped the Bony Spectre; again he threw him.
âsay mîna pâhpiw awa pâkahkos . Again the Bony Spectre laughed.

seg.gloss: “Crooked-Moccasin, by chance I stumbled over your leg; that is how you got me down.

p.seg: êyâpic pêyakwâw ! itik , pêskis êh-pâhpit awa pâkahkos . Once more!” the Bony Spectre said to him, and laughed.

êkwah ômis îtêw :
êhag , namoya êkwah kik-âstêtâmosininânaw . Then he said to him, “Yes, but this time we shall not stop for a rest.”
âsay mîna mâsihitôwak . They wrestled again.
piyisk mîna nayawîw aw âyîsiyiniw . At last the mortal man again grow tired.
mîna êh-nayawît , âsay mîna âcikêhwêw ; âsay mîna kawiwêpinêw . Again, as he wearied, he tripped the other; again he threw him to the ground.
âsay mîna pâhpiw awa pâkahkos . Again the Bony Spectre laughed.

seg.gloss: “By chance I tripped over your leg; that is how you got me down.

p.seg: êyâpic pêyakwâw ! itwêw awa pâkahkos . Once more!” said the Bony Spectre.
âsay mîna otihtinitôwak . Again they grappled.
âsay mîna êh-nayawît awa kotokwaskisin , âsay mîna âcikêhwêw . Again, as Crooked-Moccasin was tiring, he tripped the other.
sâkohêw ; kawiwêpinêw . He overcame him; he threw him.
êkwah pâhpiw awa pâkahkos . Then the Bony Spectre laughed.

seg.q: hâw , kotokwaskisin , nîswâw kêtisk ayîsiyiniwiwin kôtahon ôtah ohci .
seg.gloss: “There, Crooked-Moccasin, twice a full span of human life you have here won from me.

seg.q: âsay niyânanwâw kêtisk ayîsiyiniwak pêy-âyâwak ôtah askîhk .
seg.gloss: Already five times the full span have mortal men so far stayed on this earth.
seg.note: LB on {kêtisk}: On the meaning of this particle (given by Lacombe as “juste ce qu'il faut”) hinges the whole passage. It is not made clearer by the explanation at the end of the text. In both places, my translation is guess-work.

seg.gloss: Thus it is that I say twice.

seg.q: awa nakatamanih askiy , kotak âniskêh kit-âyisiyiniwiw .
seg.gloss: When you in your present person leave the earth, another will take up mortal life where you leave off.

seg.q: êwako nipahikêhkâci : kotak mîna êkotah ohci kit-âyisiyiniwiw .
seg.gloss: When he dies of old age, still another will from that point on live a human life.”

p.seg: nama kîkwah wâpahtam awa kotokwaskisin . Crooked-Moccasin saw nothing.
otinamiyiwa kîkwah êh-tâpiskamiyit . The other took something from round his neck.

seg.q: ôma mîna pêyak êy-otahoyan , miyêtawêyinih kit-âpacihtâyin .
seg.gloss: “Here is another thing which you have won from me, to use when you engage in contests.

seg.q: namoya wiy âyîsiyiniw kâ-kakwê-kitimahâw , têpiyâhk êkâ kêkway ta-mêskoskaman , kînikâw ohtiskawinamâski ana kê-wîcih-mêtawêmat .
seg.gloss: You will not, indeed, try to destroy people, but, only so that you need fear nothing, if he draw a sharp weapon against you, with whom you are playing.
seg.note: LB on {ta-mêskoskaman}: Another word I do not know; perhaps wrongly recorded. I translate as though it read {ta-kostaman}: “that thou fear it.”

seg.gloss: And here is my gun.

seg.q: awa kêtiskâwi-kêtisk-ayisiyiniwit , âpihtaw âpihtaw-ayisiyiniwici êyakôw âwa , kiy-ôtihtikoyêk wêmistikôsiw .
seg.gloss: When he who lives the full span of mortal life is halfway through his human course, then the Frenchman will come to where you are.
He will see the Frenchmen grow many.
At that time you will use this thing.”

p.seg: otinamiyiwa ostikwâniyihk , awîn oma , mêstakaya êh-kinwâyiki . He took it from his head, and it was nothing other than a long hair.

seg.gloss: “He will play all kinds of games; that is where you too will use it.
Now, when you go home, go directly home from here.

seg.q: kâ-wîkiyan âstam-itah kâ-sakâk , kotak âscam-itahîs apsis sakâsin .
seg.gloss: In the wood that is this side of where you dwell, a bit to this side is a small clump of trees.
From there you will get that with which to feed me.
In that place are moose; I give them to you.
You are too pitiable; you all are too pitiable who are mortal men.

p.seg: pimiy asamihkan , itik ôhi pâkahkosah ; Give me an offering of fat,” the Bony Spectre told him;

seg.q: hâ , ôm îtah kîwêhtatâ nipâskisikan ; ayisk k-ôtahon .
seg.gloss: “And yes, take home this gun of mine; for you have won it from me.”
“Yes!”

p.seg: kîwêw awa kotokwaskisin . Crooked-Moccasin went home.
awa mîna pâkahkos mîn êyako sipwêhtêw . The Bony Spectre, too, went away from there.
nama kêkway opâskisikan ; ayis otahwâw . He had no gun; he had lost it playing.

êkosi êkwah ôm âya k-âti-kîwêt awa kotokwaskisin , ôma kâ-kiskinôhamâht sakâw êh-at-ôtihtahk , kâ-wâpamât êh-nîsiyit môswah . Then when that man, Crooked-Moccasin, was on his way home, when he reached that wood about which he had been instructed, he saw two moose.
pâskiswêw ; nipahêw . He shot one and killed it.
kotakah mîna pâskiswêw ; mîn êyakoni nipahêw . He shot also the other and killed it.
mistahi wiyinoyiwa . They were very fat.
kîwêw . He went home.
pê-nâtam wiyâs . He came and got the meat.

êkwah ê-takohtatât wîkiwâhk , atoskêmôw , kahkiyaw oskanah kit-ôsikanâtamoht , pimiy êkotah ê-wih-ohtinahk . Then, when he had brought it to his dwelling, he employed people to break and boil out the bones, for he wanted to extract the marrow-fat.
tâpwê osihtâwân pimiy . Accordingly the fat was prepared for him.

ê-kîh-kîsihtâwiht , êkwah atoskêmôw , kita-têpwâtimiht ayîsiyiniwah , ê-wih-asamât pâkahkosah oma pimiy , êkwah ayîsiyiniwak ê-pîhtokêcik mîkiwâhpihk , ê-wîhkomihcik , awa kotokwaskisin wîkihk , ê-misâyik mîkiwâhp êh-âpacihtât . When it was done for him, he again employed persons, that the people might be summoned by shouting, that he might feed fat to the Bony Spectre, and that the people might come into the tipi, those who were to be guests, into Crooked-Moccasin's tipi; and he used a large tent.

êkosi êkwah oma mêkwâc kâ-ntohkêmot , êwak ohci nêwo-tipiskâyiw , ôhi kâ-kîh-mâsihât pâkahkosah . And then when he invited his guests, it was four nights from the time when he had wrestled with the Bony Spectre.

seg.gloss: “I won his gun from him, the kind of gun the Skinny Fellows have.
It is he who asked me to give him this feast of fat.

seg.q: wih-wâpahtamêko nôtahowêwin , nka-nâtên , kisiwâk ôta nikîh-pê-oyâkonêhên .
seg.gloss: If you desire to see my prize, I shall fetch it. Near by here I laid it away in the snow, as I came.”

p.seg:
êhag ! mahtih nka-wâpahtên mantôw-pâskisikan , itwêw awa pêyak kisêyiniw ,
kahkiyaw kita-wâpahtamahk , itwêw awa kisêyiniw . “Yes! Let me see the spirit being's gun,” said a certain old man, “that all may see it,” said old man.
êkwah nâtam ; ntaw-ôtinam . Then he went to fetch it; he went there and took it up.
mitoni tâpiskôc akwâhonihtak isinâkwaniyiw . It looked much like a stick of driftwood.
kîwêhtatâw . He took it to his dwelling.
êkwah awa oskâpêwis tahkih paspâpiw . Meanwhile the servitor kept looking out through the doorway.
kîtahtawê kâ-pê-takohtêyit . Presently he came.

seg.gloss: “Now then, I shall bring inside this my prize.
Therefore burn incense.

p.seg: ayisk nama wîhkâc kiwâpahtênâwâw êkosi kit-êsinâkwahk pâskisikan , itwêw . For never have you seen a gun to look like this,” he said.
wayawitimihk êh-nîpawit , miyâhkasikêwân . While he stood without, they burned incense for him.

êkwah awa kisêyiniw kâ-mamisîtotâht , - kâ-nitotamât pimâtisiwin , êkotôwahk awa kisêyiniw , - miyâw ôma pâskisikan . Then that old man upon whose power they relied, - of those that pray for life, such was that old man, - he was given the gun.
wâ-wâpahtamwak kahkiyaw . All gazed at it.

seg.gloss: “Ah!”

p.seg:
êkwah ,
hâw , pikw îtwêyêkoh nka-tôtên . Then, “Now, whatever you say, I shall do so.

seg.q: nikiskinôhamâk êkâ wîhkâc kita-patahamân kêkwah , piyâskisamâni .
seg.gloss: He instructed me so that I shall never miss a mark when I shoot.
I shall never need to load it.
As soon as I pull the trigger, that will be enough to make it shoot.”
“Well then, you had better put it away.
Never has mortal had the like of it.
You will work too much destruction.

p.seg: kiyâm ntaw-âstâh , itwêw awa kisêyiniw . You had better put it down,” said the old man.
ê-sîhkimiht kotokwaskisin kiyâm kit-âstât , tâpwêhtam . When Crooked-Moccasin was urged to give it up, he obeyed.
êkosi ntaw-âstâw ; nîpisîhkopâhk akotâw . So he went to put it away; he hung it up in a willow grove.

ômis îtwêw :
âw , nîci-pakês ! ôma pâskisikan kâwih kimiyitin . He spoke thus: “Come, my opponent at play! This gun I give back to you.

seg.q: anihi wiya kotakah êyakoni namoya kimiyitin , kêtisk ayisiyiniwin kâ-otahotân .
seg.gloss: But those other things I do not give you, the full span of life which I have won from you.
My fellows too much fear this gun of yours.

seg.q: anihi mîna kitayôwinisa kâw-otahotân , êyakonih mina namoya kâwih ka-kîh-miyitin ; oma piko kipâskisikan , êyako piko kâ-miyitân .
seg.gloss: Also those garments of yours which I have won from you, them too I cannot give back to you; only this your gun, this alone I give you.”

p.seg: nam âwiya wâpamêw ; konta pâ-pîkiskwêw . He saw no one; he continued to speak into space.
kêyâpic apiwak ayîsiyiniwak ôki kâ-wîhkomihcik . Those people who had been invited to the feast were still sitting there.
ati-kîwêw . He turned to go back.

êh-takohtêt wîkiwâhk , âsay êh-pîhtokêt , âsay kâ-matwêwêyik , ê-sâkowêyit ,
nimêmihcâciwinis ! êh-matwêy-itwêyit . When he arrived at the tipi, when he had entered, already there came the report of a gun and someone's shout, “The dear little thing I had lost!” as loudly he called.

âsay mîna kâ-matwêwêyik , âsay mîna sâkowêyiwa , âsay mîna ,
nimêmihcâciwinis ! kâ-matwêy-itwêyit . Again a shot rang out and again he whooped and cried loudly, “The dear little thing I had lost!”
kêhcinâhôwak tâpwê êh-ihtâyit ôk âyîsiyiniwak kâ-ntomihcik . Those people who had been invited then knew with certainty that that being was really there.
êwakô âcimowin kayâs . This is an ancient tale.
êwako kisêyiniw nipahikêhkâw . This old man died of age.
êkotah , ôma niya , kisêyiniwicih ayîsiyiniw , êyako pêyak kêtisk ayisiyiniw ; kotak ta-nihtâwikiw . Here, when even as I, a man grows old, that is one full span of life; another will be born.
êkoyikohk iskoh kêtisk ayisiyiniwiwin ; nam êskwa ihtâw êwako . So long is a full span of life; not yet does he exist.
kêyâpic kinwêsk kitayân askiy ; kêyâpic nama mayaw ta-pêkopayiw . Still for a long time the earth will be; not yet for a while will it go to pieces.
êkoyikohk êwako êskwâk âcimowin . That is the end of this story.
